questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. R5 is the current DR on the network, and R4 is the BDR. Their interfaces are flapping, so a network engineer wants the OSPF network to elect a different DR and BDR. Which set of configurations must the engineer implement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Max priority is 255 and all routers here have priority 1. DR/BDR election's based on highest priority!

Selected Answer: C
highest metrik is DR.
max 255
why it can't be A? It also change the DR and BDR

comments.content: because the default priority is 1. If you choose A, you're essentially increasing the priority of R4 and R5. So the Dr and BDR does not change.
DR and BDR does change, but as informed the link is flapping and this don't solve the problem.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

D is incorrect because OSPF priority range is 0-255 so its out of range

The route with a priority of 255 is selected due to the fact that this is the Max value. This forces the configuration to elect the router with this priority. It is not recommended to use priority 255 unless it is really necessary.
It took me a while to realize that router 3 is NOT in the OSPF “neighborhood” (check the exhibit). Maybe that’s why answer A is correct and C is not.

comments.content: I’m sorry. My bad here. Disregard my previous comment. Of course router 3 is in the OSPF neighborhood.
its because the command was done on R3 so the list shows its neighbors

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The question only asks us to change the current conditions. So both A and C provide the answer. This question is broken. Anyway I will go with C

Selected Answer: C
The answer is C - manually forcing the priority

comments.content: I messed up OSPF's default priority value is 1 so A would do nothing. ANSWER IS C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This really depends on what the question is trying to ask.
Yes option C will also achieve the same effect but you are manually forcing R3 and R2 to become DR and BDR. The question only asked for you to have OSPF elect a different DR and BDR so I think A fits best as it will leave OSPF to elect a DR and BDR instead of you basically forcing it.
why not D?

comments.content: OSPF priority range is 0-255. D is out of range

because the value can go from 0 to 255 (default = 1): with 0 you avoid the election to DR / BDR, with higher values you can drive it at will. If all the routers on the LAN have priority = 0, OSPF will not work

choices.D: R2(config)#interface gi0/0 R2(config-if)#ip ospf priority 259 R3(config)#interface gi0/0 R3(config-if)#ip ospf priority 256
choices.A: R4(config)#interface gi0/0 R4(config-if)#ip ospf priority 20 R5(config)#interface gi0/0 R5(config-if)#ip ospf priority 10
choices.B: R5(config)#interface gi0/0 R5(config-if)#ip ospf priority 120 R4(config)#interface gi0/0 R4(config-if)#ip ospf priority 110
choices.C: R3(config)#interface gi0/0 R3(config-if)#ip ospf priority 255 R2(config)#interface gi0/0 R2(config-if)#ip ospf priority 240

comments.content: Since everyone who replied so far doesn't seem to understand my question let me clarify. IRL you should only get one routing entry per network route from the show routing table command; unless you configured load balancing. Obliviously EIGRP has lower AD than OSPF which is why only the EIGRP route should be shown in this show command. I'm asking how on earth could there be an OSPF and EIGRP entry in this show command when there should only be 1 entry for the network route as to my knowledge and google there doesn't seem to be a way you can load balance between 2 routing protocols.
Plain and simple: This is a cooked up table. There can't be.

Let me repeat on behalf of the comment above:
"Plain and simple: This is a cooked up table. There can't be"
You didn't answer my question. IRL you wouldn't event see the OSPF route because the router would've selected the EIGRP route already due to it having a lower AD. So this show command is unrealistic.
relax, this made just to test the knowledge. just answer the question then your good to go the next question. don't over think.
OSPF AD=110 EIGRP AD=90 ,so i think choose A

networkin answered your question above like this....
Plain and simple: This is a cooked up table. There can't be

You know when I first took an exam with Cisco, there were physical devices, and we needed to configure OSPF.

I put in all my knowledge, and it didn't work, one of the routers just couldn't be bothered to answer pings.

I went to our teacher after the exam when I got my F grade, to ask him to show me how to do it.

The device was bugged, and I was given another shot to pass the exam.
There COULD be IRL scenarios like this, as there are numerous bugs and "other" events not even Cisco has control over.

"Administrative distance is the first criterion that a router uses to determine which routing protocol to use if two protocols provide route information for the same destination. Administrative distance is a measure of the trustworthiness of the source of the routing information"
The smaller the AD value, the more reliable the protocol. In this case, EIGRP wins because it has a smaller AD

discussion.content: I really need someone to explain to me how there is an OSPF and EIGRP entry for the same network in this routing table.
Longest prefix is the same for both route on 10.0.10 network. AD takes the charge to determine the route

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

There can be multiple routing protocols at work simultaneous.
This is what we call "Ships In the Night" (a SIN) - get it?
See "Routing TCP/IP volume 1" by Jeff Doyle (a must have textbook for CCNP/CCIE).

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Web traffic is coming in from the WAN interface. Which route takes precedence when the router is processing traffic destined for the LAN network at 10.0.10.0/24?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
The destination is the last host of the 10.10.8.0/28 subnet. So the mask of the destination is /28 aka 255.255.255.240
Correct Answer is B. 255.255.255.240, means /28. The IP 10.10.8.14 falls within the 10.10.8.0/28 range, which is: 10.10.8.0 network ID - 10.10.8.15 Broadcast IP.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A 
The destination route is default route 172.16.2.2.
172.16.2.0/23 is directly connected g0/0/1
255.255.254.0

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A packet sourced from 10.10.10.1 is destined for 10.10.8.14. What is the subnet mask of the destination route?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer must configure router R2 so it is elected as the DR on the WAN subnet. Which command sequence must be configured?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It is me or the network configuration on R1 is full of shit ?

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
you can answer this question even if you don't know the OSPF
please pay close attention to details 10.0.0.34
why not c?

comments.content:
Because of the IP Address configuration, it needs to be indented from the 10.0.0.32/27 network (host 10.0.0.33 to 10.0.0.62 - Broadcast 10.0.0.63).
Prefix 27 minus 32 = 5 left over used for host (1=2 - 2=4 - 3=8 - 4=16 - 5=32), i.e. we have a range of 32 hosts available in each subnet:
Subnet 10.0.0.0 - 10.0.0.32 - 10.0.0.64 - 10.0.0.96 - 10.0.0.128 - 10.0.0.160 - 10.0.0.192 - 10.0.0.224.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer B is correct:
Network on G0/0 is 10.0.0.32/27 ===> 10.0.0.34 255.255.255.224 with priority higher then default (1) , 100

comments.content: How did you get 10.0.0.34? I can if the answer is 10.0.0.33 but not 34. Thank you for your time in advance.
Nevermind, I just saw the .34 next to R2!! I really need to pay attention to detail!

choices.B: interface gigabitethernet0/0 ip address 10.0.0.34 255.255.255.224 ip ospf priority 100
choices.D: interface gigabitethernet0/0 ip address 10.0.1.1 255.255.255.224 ip ospf priority 98
choices.A: interface gigabitethernet0/0 ip address 10.0.0.34 255.255.255.248 ip ospf priority 0
choices.C: interface gigabitethernet0/0 ip address 10.0.1.1 255.255.255.0 ip ospf priority 255

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
C is incorrect because the command is entered in the interface R1(config-if). The default route must be entered in the glocal config. Making D the correct answer.

The correct answer is not an option.

you must specify the following
R1(config)#ipv6 route 2019:C15C:0CAF:E001::/64 GigabitEthernet 0/0 2019:C15C:0CAF:E002::1
Tested in Packet Tracer, you can not create a route from the config-if menu, therefore D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
a static route with ipv6 should be configured in global configuration mode.

The part about the interface is entirely misdirection. The primary focus is on the next hop, sending all traffic for that prefix out of G0/0 does not ensure the next hop will be 2019:C15C:0CAF:E002::1

I think they put the G0/0 interface in there to throw people off. I was taught the command is Ipv6 route destination ( 2019:C15C:0CAF:E001) prefix length ( /64) next-hop (2019:C15C:0CAF:E002::1), so yea D is correct
C must be wrong, cause who tell you the R1(config-if) must be the interface G0/0?

WHY NOT B,

IT'S CONFIRUED IN GLOBAL CONFIG MODE, IT USED DESTINATION IP AND EXIT INTEREFACE .

PLEASE EXPLAIN SOMEONE

comments.content: where are the source and dest?
'ip route' is incorrect.
Thanks for this...I just missed "ipv6"

discussion.content:
ChatGPT:
Here's how you would configure the IPv6 static route in global configuration mode:

 Enter global configuration mode:



R1# configure terminal

 Add the IPv6 static route using the ipv6 route command:



R1(config)# ipv6 route 2019:C15C:0CAF:E001::/64 2019:C15C:0CAF:E002::1 Gigabit0/0

 Exit configuration mode and save the configuration:


R1(config)# end
R1# write memory

This will add the specified IPv6 static route to the routing table, and the router will forward packets for the destination prefix 2019:C15C:0CAF:E001::/64 to the next hop address 2019:C15C:0CAF:E002::1 via the Gigabit0/0 interface.

comments.content: In Packet Tracer, as with most Cisco routers, the ipv6 route command should be configured in global configuration mode. This command is used to add an IPv6 static route in the routing table of the router, so it should be applied in the global context to affect the entire router's behavior.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
it says "The route must be reachable via the R1 Gigabit 0/0 interface."

Selected Answer: D
the ipv6 instead of ip got me good with this one
Admin please input your explanation for this question. I'm finally smashing Routing but questions like these will put us off.

Selected Answer: C
It's an ipv6 address and the Answer says this : "The route must be reachable via the R1 Gigabit 0/0 interface." Then then you need to ingres the comand on G0/0 interface or in global config but adding G0/0 . C is correct.
bcz next hop address is global unicast address not link local address

comments.content: A fully specified route would be better, considering the formatting of the question but I suppose the one we were given is the next best, especially considering that the rest of the asnwers are blatantly wrong.

discussion.content: shouldn't be R1(config)#ipv6 route 2019:C15C:0CAF:E001::/64 g0/1 2019:C15C:0CAF:E002::1 ?

comments.content: C is also valid. Global configuration mode commands (ipv6 route) can be given in interface configuration mode (but not the other way around). I doubt that at the exam they will ask us to choose between exactly these correct options, probably the question here is defective.
nope, static route must be configure in global configuration mode. Answer is D which is definietly reachable by G0/0 interface.
The Answer says this "The route must be reachable via the R1 Gigabit 0/0 interface." Then then you need to ingres the comand on G0/0 interface. C is correct.
Because C shows the command being entered on an interface (config-if).

discussion.content: why not C?

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring router R1 with an IPv6 static route for prefix 2019:C15C:0CAF:E001::/64. The next hop must be 2019:C15C:0CAF:E002::1. The route must be reachable via the R1 Gigabit 0/0 interface. Which command configures the designated route?
